turns.speaker: MÜLLER
turns.text: Is this you?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: MÜLLER
turns.text: It is you.  This was taken in Cairo at British Headquarters - July 41. And so was this - August 41.  And this -February 42.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: It's impossible.  I was buying or selling something.  I've been to Cairo many times.

turns.speaker: MÜLLER
turns.text: You are a Canadian spy working for the Allies.  Code-name Moose.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Yes, I've been asking for weeks, a month, I don't know, also my leg was -

turns.speaker: MÜLLER
turns.text: We don't have a doctor, but we do have a nurse.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: A nurse?  Well, sure, a nurse is great. A nurse?  Great.

turns.speaker: MÜLLER
turns.text: Why is there so much nose?  I can't hear myself think!  Look - give me something.  So we can all get out of this room.  A name.  A code.  It's too hot.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: I slept with the girl.  I've got a wife in Tripoli.  A girl comes up and points at you, you only see trouble.

turns.speaker: MÜLLER
turns.text: Well, you must know.  You were brought up Libya, yes?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Don't cut me.

turns.speaker: MÜLLER
turns.text: Or was it Toronto?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Don't cut me.  Come on.

turns.speaker: MÜLLER
turns.text: Go!  Hey!  Go! Caravaggio is in terror.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Oh Jesus.  Oh Jesus Christ.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Buon' Giorno! Hana turns, startled and suspicious.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Are you Hana?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: I met your friend Mary.  She said I should stop and see if you were okay. Apparently we're neighbors - my house is two blocks from yours in Montreal. Cabot, north of Laurier.  Bonjour.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Bonjour.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: They're fresh.  I haven't eaten an egg inhave you noticed there are chickens? You get chickens in Italy but no eggs. In Africa there were always eggs, but never chickens. Who separates them?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: You were in Africa?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Yeah, for a while.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: So was my Patient.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: I'd like to stay.  That's the long and short of it.  I mean, you know blah-blah if it's convenient, if there's room blah-blah-blah.  I have to do some work here -I speak the language. There are Partisans to be -  -we embrace them and see if we can relieve them of their weapons, you know - while we hug.  I was a thief, so they think I'd be good at that.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: So you can shoot a pistol?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: If you said yes I would have had a reason.  You should let me redress those bandages.  Before you go.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: I'm okay.  Look, it's a big house. We needn't disturb each other.  I can shoot a pistol!  I'll sleep in the stables.  I don't care where I sleep.  I don't sleep.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Because we're fine here.  I don't know what Mary told you about me, but I don't need company, I don't need to be looked at.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Fine.  I'm not looking.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Supper. Hana calls after him.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Where've you been?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Rabbit hunting.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I could help you.  I could get you off that.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Can you cook the rabbit or will you try and bring that back to life?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: It's a week.  We didn't know where you were - or if you coming back, or -

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: You should be happy.  What were you going to do for him when it ran out? He pulls out more phials from his jacket.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: What do you do?  What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Some gave me a dress.  You know what's great?  What I'm learning? You win a war and you not only gain the miles you get the moral ground. Everywhere I go, we're in the right. I like that.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Hana?  Hana?  Are you alright?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Don't touch me if you're going to try and fuck me.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: I'll have some of your water.  It's hot.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: You have to protect yourself from sadness.  This is the thing I've learned.  You're in love with him, aren't you? Your patient.  Do you think he's a saint or something?  Because of the way he looks?  I don't think he is.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I'm not in love with him.  I'm in love with ghosts.  And so is he. He's in love with ghosts.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Who are his ghosts?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Ask him.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: What if I told you he did this to me?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: What?  How could he have?  When?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: I'm one of his ghosts and he wouldn't even know.  It's like he slammed a door in Cairo and it trapped my fucking hands in Tobruk.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I don't know what that means.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Ask him.  Ask your saint who he is. Ask him who he's killed.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Please don't creep around this house.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Where did you find that?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: I liberated it.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I think that's called looting.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: No-one should own music.  The real question is who wrote the song?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Well, then ask him his name!

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: What's happened?  Kip!  What's happening? Don't shoot, please, don't shoot anybody.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Buon' giorno.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: She can take you as far as Florence.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I can get in the back.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Finally!  So you're our Canadian pickpocket?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Thief, I think, is more accurate.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I understand you were in Africa. Whereabouts?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Oh, all over.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: All over?  I kept trying to cover a very modest portion and still failed.  Are you leaving us?  Now's our opportunity to swap war wounds.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I think anybody she ever loves tends to die on her.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Are you planning to be the exception?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Me?  You've got the wrong end of the stick, old boy.  So - Caravaggio - Hana thinks you invented your name.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: And you've forgotten yours.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I told her you would never invent such a preposterous name.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: I told her you can forget everything but you never forget your name.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Are you outside? A beat and then Caravaggio shuffles in.  Like an old boxer.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: I can't hide anymore.  I breathe like a dog.  I lose my balance.  Stealing's got harder. Caravaggio stares at the Herodotus.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Why do I feel if I had your book I would know everything?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I don't even know if it is my book. The Bedouin found it in the plane, in the wreckage.  It's mine now. I heard your breathing and thought it might be rain. I'm dying for rain - of course I'm dying anyway - but I long to feel rain on my face.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Is it you?  If I said Moose I look different, fuck, why shouldn't you?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Moose.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: First wedding anniversary - what do you call it?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I don't know.  Paper.  Is it? Paper?  I don't remember.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Thought you'd never wake up!

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: What? Hana comes in, sleepily, frowns at the gramophone.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Irving Berlin.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: For?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Top Hat.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Is there a song you don't know?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Have a drink.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I've had a drink.  Fatal.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Well, anything you do is likely to be fatal, so you know -

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Very true!

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: What?  You and Madox?  Or you and Katharine Clifton?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Hana tells me you're leaving.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: There are going to be trials, they want me to interpret, don't they know I'm allergic to courtrooms?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: We shall miss you.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: So, I come across the Hospital Convoy  I was looking for this stuff, and some nurse, Mary, Hana's friend, tells me about you and Hana, hiding in a monastery, in purdah, whatever it is - retreat -  how you'd come in from the Desert and you were burned and you didn't know your name but you knew the words to every song there was and you had one possession -  - a copy of Herodotus - and it was full of letters and cuttings, and then I knew it must be you.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: I'd seen you writing in that book. At the Embassy in Cairo, when I had thumbs and you had a face. And a name.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: Before you went over to the Germans, before you got Rommel's spy across the desert and inside British headquarters. He took some pretty good photographs - I saw mine in that torture room in Tobruk, so they made an impression.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: And you thought you'd come and settle the score?

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: You were the only man who knew the desert well enough, the only man who would cross seventeen hundred miles of nothing.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I had to get back to the desert. I made a promise.  The rest meant nothing to me.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: The rest meant nothing to me.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: There was a result to what you did. It wasn't just another expedition.  It did this.  If the British hadn't unearthed your nosey photographer in Cairo thousands of people could have died.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Thousands of people did die, just different people.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: But you were among the British, they were your friends - why betray them?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Is that what you thought?  That I betrayed the British?  The British betrayed me.  The British betrayed me.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: And did you never see Katharine? You never got back to the Cave?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, I got back there finally to keep my promise.  To come back for her. And then of course I couldn't I couldn't even do that properly.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: You get to the morning and the poison leaks away, doesn't it? Black nights, fucking black nights, when you want to howl like a dog. I thought I would kill you.  You killed my friends, you ruined my hands.  But the girl was always here, like some Guardian Angel.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: You can't kill me.  I died years ago.

turns.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
turns.text: No, now I can't kill you.

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: But then the Queen looked up and saw Gyges concealed in the shadows. And though she said nothing, she shuddered. The next day she sent for Gyges and challenged him.  And hearing his story, she said this -

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Off with his head!

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: The team is in mourning, darling.

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: Oh really?

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: I was just saying, I'm going to cable Downing Street, see if I can't stir up a few shillings - Katharine's mother and the PM's wife are best -

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: Darling, for goodness' sake!

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Well, she is!

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: Why do you think?  About my staying?

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Well look, if nobody minds, truly, then I suppose - I shall, of course, be bereft

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: But finally able to explore the Cairo night-life. I shall produce an authoritative guide to the Zinc Bars and - I want to say Harems - am I in the right country for Harems?

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Darling, I just heard.  You poor sausage, are you all right?

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: I'm fine.  I got hot.

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Lady H said she thought you might be -

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: I'm not pregnant.  I'm hot.  I'm too hot.

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: Aren't you?

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Sweltering.  Come on, I'll take you home.

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: Can't we really go home?  I can't breathe. Aren't you dying for green, anything green, or rain, wouldn't you die to feel rain on your face? It's Christmas and it's all - I don't know - if you asked me I'd go home tomorrow.  If you wanted.

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Sweetheart, you know we can't go home, there might be a war.

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: Geoffrey, you do so love putting on a disguise.

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: I do so love you.  What do you smell of?

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Marzipan!  I think you've got marzipan in your hair.  No wonder you're homesick.

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: Marvelous plane.  Did you look?

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Isn't it?  Wedding present from Katharine's parents.  I'm calling it Rupert Bear.  Hello.  Geoffrey Clifton.

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: We can finally consign my old bird to the scrapheap. Almásy smiles and walks on towards the others.

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: I think you know all of us, except for Geoffrey and Katharine Clifton, who've recently come out from England.

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Apprentices.

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: This is Clive Fenelon-Barnes.

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: Of course.  Well, we should all go out onto the terrace.

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Oh no, really.  She has her book.

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: I won't hear of it.  None of us will.

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Good heavens, are you married, Madox?

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: Very much so.  We are all, save my friend here.

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: And a special thank you to Geoffrey and Katharine, without whose fund raising heroics we should still be kicking our heels. They toast the Cliftons.

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: To arm-twisting.

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: Did Katharine say? - Geoffrey has to fly back to Cairo.

turns.speaker: CLIFTON
turns.text: Have to return the favor - take a few photographs for the army.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: There was a Prince, who was dying, and he was carried up the tower at Pisa so he could die with a view of the Tuscan Hills. Am I that Prince? Hana laughs.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Because you're leaning?  No, you're just on an angle.  You're too heavy!

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: What was all the banging?  Were you fighting rats or the entire German army?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I was repairing the stairs.  I found a library and the books were very useful.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Before you find too many uses for these books would you read some to me?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I think they're all in Italian, but I'll look, yes.  What about your own book?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: My book?  The Herodotus?  Yes, we can read him.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Oh - I've found plums.  We have plums in the orchard.  We have an orchard! She has peeled a plum and now slips it into his mouth.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I will hide you in the room where we sleep, said Candaules. She stumbles over the word.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Candaules

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Candaulesyou're laughing at me.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I'm not laughing at you.  Go on, please.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: When my wife comes to lie down she always lays her garments one by one on a seat near the entrance of the room, and from where you stand you will be able to gaze on her at your leisure

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Are you asleep?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Yes.  Dropping off.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I should try and move your bed.  I want you to be able to see the view.  It's good, it's a view from a monastery.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I can already see.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: How?  How can you see anything?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Not the window - I can't bear the light anyway - no, I can see all the way to the desert.  I've found the lost fossils.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I'm turning you.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Zerzura, the White City of Acacias, the Oasis of Little Birds.  As me about the scent of acacia - it's in this room.  I can smell it.  The taste of tea so black it falls into your mouth.  I can taste it. I'm chewing the mint.  Is there sand in my eyes?  Are you cleaning sand from my ears?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: No sand.  That's your drugs speaking.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I can see my wife in that view.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Are you remembering more?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Could I have a cigarette?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Are you crazy?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Why are you so determined to keep me alive?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Because I'm a nurse.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: There's a man downstairs.  He brought us eggs.  He might stay.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Why?  Can he lay eggs?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: He's Canadian.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Why are people always so happy when they collide with someone from the same place?  What happened in Montreal when you passed a man in the street - did you invite him to live with you?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: He needn't disturb you.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Me?  He can't.  I'm already disturbed.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: He won't disturb us then.  I think he's after morphine.  There's a war.  Where you come from becomes important.  And besides - we're vulnerable here. I keep hearing noises in the night. Voices.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Excuse me -

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Can I ask - my friend, can he come in? Just for a few minutes?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Your friend?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: He's going back to the front this evening.  I can't see him otherwise.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Just go off.  I'll be quite all right.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: No, I can't go, but if it, if you weren't offended, it would be very good of you to allow us - every other cabin is crammed. This is as private as we'll get.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Well then - yes.  Of course.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Thank you.  Thank you.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: This is Captain McGann.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Please, don't waste your time on pleasantries -

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Something smells so rich.  My stomach is heaving -

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: He came back, he says he caught a rabbit.  I'm cooking it.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: That's a different dress.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: He keeps asking me questions about you. Do you know him?  Do you recognize him?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Do I recognize him?  I recognize what he is. I like him.  He's Canadian.  He can read Italian.  He can catch rabbits.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Could I ask you to move?  I'm sorry - but when you turn, the sheets, I can't really bear the sheets moving over me. Sorry.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Yes, of course, I'm so sorry. Stupid of me. Hana gets up, upset to have hurt him.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Tell me about this, this is in your handwriting - December 22nd - Betrayals in war are childlike compared with our betrayals during peace.  New lovers are nervous and tender, but smash everything - for the heart is an organ of fire  I love that, I believe that.  Who is K?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: K is for Katharine.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: He wants us to move out, says there could be fifty more mines in the building. He thinks I'm mad because I laughed at him.  He's Indian, he wears a turban.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Sikh.  If he wears a turban, he's a Sikh.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I'll probably marry him.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Really?  That's sudden.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: My mother always told me I would summon my husband by playing the piano.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I liked it better when there were just the two of us.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Why?  Is he staying?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: With his Sergeant.  A Mr. Hardy.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: We should charge!  Doesn't anyone have a job to do?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: They have to clear all the local roads of mines.  That's a big job. They won't stay in the house. They're putting up their tent in the garden.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: In that case, I suppose we can't charge.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Good morning.  Did you know that?  You're always singing?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I've been told that before.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Kip's another one.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Arguing about books.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Condensed milk - one of the truly great inventions.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: You like him, don't you?  Your voice changes.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I don't think it does.  Anyway, he's indifferent to me.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I don't think it's indifference.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Hana was just telling me that you were indifferent -

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Hey! -

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: - to her cooking.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: I'm still here.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: You'd better be.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Don't depend on it.  Will you? That little bit of air, each day there's less of it, which is al right, which is quite all right.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Why don't you go?  You should sleep.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Would you like me to?

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: Who knows the Bosphorus Hug?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Never heard of it.

turns.speaker: THE PATIENT
turns.text: That was a dance we invented at the International Sand Club.

turns.speaker: JAN
turns.text: There's meant to be lace in the next village - the boys are taking me.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I'm not sewing anything else.

turns.speaker: JAN
turns.text: You don't have any money, do you? Just in case there's silk.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: JAN
turns.text: Hana, I know you do!

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I'm not sewing anything else for you!

turns.speaker: JAN
turns.text: I love you.

turns.speaker: JAN
turns.text: Where's your Stuart from? Somewhere near there, isn't it?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Excuse me.  Yes?  I don't have the key to that door.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: The Germans were here.  The Germans were all over this area.  They left mines everywhere.  Pianos were their favorite hiding places.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I see.  Then may be you're safe as long as you only play Bach.  He's German. Kip is looking around the piano. Hana giggles.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: Is something funny?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: No, but, no, not at all.  I'm sorry. You came to the doors, that's all and -  - such good manners for someone worried about mines.  That's all.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: I've met you before.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Try this.  I found a great jar of it. Olive oil.  In Naples this was so precious it would have bought you a wife.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: For my hair?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Yes, for your hair.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: I'll get another tin. Hana and the Patient are alone.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I didn't like that book either. It's all about men.  Too many men. Just like this house.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: It's okay - I'll help.  Please.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: The mines, the wires, there's a trick. Some explode if you stretch the wires, some if you cut them.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: What do I do?

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: There's a mine here, but the others are far enough away, I think at least to give me a chance.  I have to work out which one to cut before I fall over.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: So I follow the wires?

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: You get Hardy.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I follow the wires.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Why would anyone do this?

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: I've done this.  I've had to do this.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: What is this business with you and explosives?  Do you think you're immune?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I promise you that was the right thing to do.  He's my good luck.  Now cut.  This one.  I hope we don't die.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: Okay.  Get away from here.  Quick.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I'm not scared.  So many people have died around me.  But I would be a shame for us.  I don't feel like being shy.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: You must get away.  Before I cut. I'm not cutting if you're here. He's struggling.  He's going to topple over if he cuts.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Actually, you can't cut, can you? You'll fall over.  Give me the pliers.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: No. But he hands them over.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Kiss me.  Before I cut.  Just in case.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: Don't talk.  Check again.  Lie flat and then cut.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Don't go.  I'm frightened.  I can love a coward, I can't love another dead man.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: This is what I do.  I do this every day.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Kip - come and dance with me

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: Yes.  Later.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: I was thinking yesterday - yesterday! - the Patient, Hardy: they're everything that's good about England. I couldn't even say what that was. We didn't exchange two personal words, and we've been together through some terrible things, some -  he was engaged to a girl in the village! - I mean -  and us - he never once He didn't ask me if I could spin the ball at cricket or the kamasutra or - I don't even know what I'm talking about.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: You loved him.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: If one night I didn't come to the tent, what would you do?

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: I try not to expect you.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: But if it got late and I hadn't shown up?

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: Then I'd think there must be a reason.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: You wouldn't come to find me?  That makes me never want to come here. But she continues unraveling the turban.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: What are you up to?

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: That gun at Lahor, Kipling's cannon - Zamzammah - remember?  That was made out of the metal of ordinary things. I want to make an ordinary thing out of guns. His bayonet is thrust into the forge.  It's red hot.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: When I went to England I was amazed at what went on, the waste - I'd been taught to re-use everything, the dung from a cow to cool a radiator, a fork to fix a typewriter - India could live for a hundred years on what I saw thrown away.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I should go to the house, get breakfast.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: The lamp was burning all night in his room.  Caravaggio was there with him.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: This is hot!

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Nya-nya-nya!

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: Will you come with me?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Of course.  When?

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: I mean home.  India.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Kip I -

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: I know - here I am always a brown man, there you would be always a white woman.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Is that what you think?  Is that what you think I think?

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: It's what I've learned.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I'm thinking about your heart, not your skin.  And how to reach it. And that I don't think I can.  A bomb has ruined us, just not the bomb I thought would ruin us.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I've clung to you.  I've clung to you. Kip.  Life  a raft.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: Then come with me.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I'll always go back to that church. Look at my painting.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: I'll always go back to that church.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: So one day we'll meet.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: The war's over - you told me yourself. How can it be desertion?

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: It's not over everywhere.  I didn't mean literally.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: When he dies I'll catch up.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: It's not safe here.  The whole country's crawling with Bandits and Germans and God knows what.  It's madness.  I can't allow it. You're not, this is natural - it's shock. For all of us.  Hana -

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I need morphine.  A lot.  And a pistol.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: And what if he really is a spy?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: He can't even move.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: If anything happened to you I'd never forgive myself.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Why Picton?

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: He's from there - edge of Lake Ontario right, Soldier?

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Third Canadian Fusiliers.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Does he know a Captain McGann? The boy hears this, whispers to Oliver.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: He's gone, hasn't he?

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: No.  He's - no.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Oh God.  Oh God.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Hello miss.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I was going to say - if you want to eat with us, ever you and Lieutenant Singh

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Very kind of you, we can always eat in the town with the others -

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Since Caravaggio turned up - food seems to appear, so please.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: I'll ask the Lieutenant.  But thank you.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: You saved my life.  I haven't forgotten.  I thought you were very very tall. You seemed to big - a Giant - and I felt like a child who can't keep her balance.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: A toddler

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: I was looking for the Lieutenant Singh.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: He's sleeping.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Only we have to go to work.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I'll tell him.  What is it?  Is it a mine?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: A bomb.  At the Viaduct. She closes the door, then reappears.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Does he have to go?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Pardon me?

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: What if you couldn't find him?  Sergeant, not today, please. Not this morning.

turns.speaker: STUART
turns.text: Whoa - give me a chance!

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: Sorry.  I took a Benzedrine.

turns.speaker: STUART
turns.text: I've got a surprise.  A boat!  We can go to Capri.  It's got a cabin, it's private.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I'd like to spend a night with you in a bed.

turns.speaker: STUART
turns.text: We can do that when we're very, very old.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: You've got a mustache.

turns.speaker: STUART
turns.text: A bit of one.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I was looking forward to this evening.

turns.speaker: STUART
turns.text: I had a hotel room.

turns.speaker: HANA
turns.text: I thought that was for when we were very very old?

turns.speaker: STUART
turns.text: I'm feeling old.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: Hey!  Hey!  Stop!  Hey!

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Don't move!  Stand ABSOLUTELY STILL! Hana stops.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: What's happening?  Am I needed?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: I'm afraid so, sir. Kip hurries to his tent.  Hana follows him.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: You've got to cut, sir, that frost won't last.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: Go away.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Yessir.

turns.speaker: KIP
turns.text: This is making me incredibly angry.

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: Your book.  Your Herodotus! Almásy looks uncomfortable.

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: It doesn't matter.  Really.  I think I can muddle through.  Okay - The Story of Candaules and Gyges. King Candaules was passionately in love with his wife -  One day he said to Gyges, the son of somebody, anyway - his favorite warrior -

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: Mrs. Clifton, you'll have to forgive us.  We're not accustomed to the company of women.

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: Not at all.  I was thoroughly enjoying by book.  Please.  Signor D'Agostino, Herr Bermann.

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: I'm afraid we're not having much luck obtaining funds for the expedition.

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: How awful.  What will you do?

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: A more modest expedition, or even wait a year.  Remind our families we still exist.

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: Darling, Peter says I could stay

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: MADOX
turns.text: Certainly not.

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: I insist.  There clearly isn't room for us all, I'm the least able to dig, and I'm not one of the walking wounded. Those are facts.  Besides, if I remain it's the most effective method of persuading my husband to abandon whatever he's doing and rescue us. It's hard to argue with this logic.

turns.speaker: LADY HAMPTON
turns.text: Katharine!

turns.speaker: KATHARINE
turns.text: Coming.  I can't sleep.  I woke up shouting in the middle of the night. Geoffrey thinks it's the thing in the desert, the trauma.
